fields:
Pathogen - {{c1::any organism with the potential to cause disease}}
Opportunistic pathogen - {{c1::organism that causes disease only in individuals whose immune system is some way compromised}}
SLO: Distinguish between a pathogen and an opportunistic pathogen.

Non-self: {{c1::Pathogens; immune system responds to foreign things in the body}}
Self: {{c1::immune system does not react}}
Distinguish between self and non-self.  How does this relate to immunological tolerance?

! Ways cell gene expression can be controlled or disrupted!

Transcriptional regulation: 
- Adding {{c1::methyl groups}} on the {{c1::sequence}} a transcription factor needs to bind to will {{c1::decrease}} transcription of a gene and it's expression.  
- Mutations or methylation of introns can cause {{c1::improper splicing}} (removal of interons), causing {{c1::exons}} to be left out or junk introns being left in the final {{c1::mRNA transcript}}. This messes up the proteins shape causing it to be {{c1::ubiquitied}} (targeted for destruction) by the {{c1::unfolded protein response}} (UPR). 

Translational Regulation 
- Micro RNAs (miRNA) can {{c1::bind to an mRNA transcript}} causing it to jam when trying to be {{c1::translated by the ribosome}}. 

Histone regulation 
- {{c1::HATS}} Open up histones {{c1::(increasing transcriptional access and gene expression)}} by adding negative acytal groups. 
- {{c1::DACS}} deacetylate histones {{c1::(decrease transcriptional access and gene expression)}} allowing the now more positive histones hold negative DNA more tightly.
* Differentiate the means in which gene expression can be controlled or disrupted. (1 Q on exam involving methylation or histones)
Describe how metabolic fuels are used
SLO: Describe how metabolic fuels are used and stored
Describe how metabolic fuels are stored
SLO: Describe how metabolic fuels are used and stored

Describe the role glucose as a fuel source in different tissues. 

These cells use glucose as their primary energy source: {{c1::Neurons}} (brain tissue), {{c1::RBCs}} (contain no mitochondria).

Normal blood glucose levels peak {{c1::1}} hour after a meal then should be {{c1::80-100}} mg/dl {{c1::2}} hours after eating... Mercedies!
* Describe the role glucose as a fuel source in different tissues.

Fed State 
  • Digestive tract breaks down carbs into {{c1::monosaccharides}} (simple sugars like glucose) and proteins into amino acids which go to {{c1::liver, brain, and muscles}}.  
  • Liver starts creating these 3 important things: 
    • 1. {{c1::Glycogen}} in a process called glycogenosis using {{c1::monosaccharides}} from digestion. 
    • 2. {{c1::Triacylglycerols}} in the process of Triacylglycerol Synthesis using {{c1::monosaccharides}} from digestion. 
    • 3. {{c1::Albumin}} using Amino acids from digestion.  
  • Adipose tissue stores fat droplets that it creates from triacylglycerols sent through the blood on chylomicrons (cholesterol balls) from the intestinal epithelial cells. 
Fasting State 
  • Liver starts {{c1::glycogenolysis}} to break down glycogen and breaks down {{c1::fatty acids}} into ketone bodes. 
  • Adipose tissue begins {{c1::lipolysis}} which oxidizes triacylglycerols to produce either {{c1::acetyl-coA}} for the Krebs aka {{c1::tricarboxylic acid}} (TCA) cycle. Can also oxidizes triacylglycerols into {{c1::ketone}} bodies.
* Compare and contrast metabolic processes during the fed and fasting states.
Describe the role of hormones in regulating metabolic pathways

Hormones: {{c1::secreted systemically in the circulation}}
  • {{c1::Gastrin, cholecystokinin (CCK), secretin, Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide (GIP), motilin::Examples?}} 
Paracrines: {{c1::diffuse short distances to nearby target cells}}
  • {{c1::Somatostatin, histamine::Examples?}}
Neurocrines: {{c1::released in response to an action potential across a synapse onto specific target cells }}
  • {{c1::Ach, NE, Gastrin-Releasing Peptide (GRP aka Bombesin), enkephalins (opiates)::Examples?}}
** SLO 18. Differentiate between mechanisms of hormones, paracrines, and neurocrines

**SLO 19: For gastrin, CCK, Secretin, GIP, and motilin: know the stimuli for secretion, inhibiting factors, cell type that secretes it and location (just stomach vs duodenum is adequate), and actions. Note: we will discus CCK, secretin, and GIP again)

**SLO 19: For gastrin, CCK, Secretin, GIP, and motilin: know the stimuli for secretion, inhibiting factors, cell type that secretes it and location (just stomach vs duodenum is adequate), and actions. Note: we will discus CCK, secretin, and GIP again)

**SLO 19: For gastrin, CCK, Secretin, GIP, and motilin: know the stimuli for secretion, inhibiting factors, cell type that secretes it and location (just stomach vs duodenum is adequate), and actions. Note: we will discus CCK, secretin, and GIP again)
**SLO 20: For somatostatin, histamine, and GRP: know the stimuli for release, inhibiting factors, cell type that secretes it and location (just stomach vs duodenum is adequate), and actions
**SLO 20: For somatostatin, histamine, and GRP: know the stimuli for release, inhibiting factors, cell type that secretes it and location (just stomach vs duodenum is adequate), and actions
**SLO 20: For somatostatin, histamine, and GRP: know the stimuli for release, inhibiting factors, cell type that secretes it and location (just stomach vs duodenum is adequate), and actions

Function of saliva: {{c1::initial digestion, buffers acidic food, and lubricates food to facilitate swallowing}}
Structure of salivary glands: {{c1::branching duct system ending in acini}}
Composition of saliva: {{c1::mucous, Na, K, Cl, HCO3, and proteins}}
  • Digestive enzymes: {{c1::amylase (digests carbs), lipase (digests fats)}}
  • Antimicrobials: {{c1::IgA, lysozymes}}
Modification occurs during transit through the duct
  • The lower the saliva flow rate, {{c1::the more ductal modification (and vise versa)}}
  • This is something that tends to come up regularly despite questionable clinical significance
Three primary salivary glands:
  1. {{c1::Parotid}}
  2. {{c1::Sublingual}}
  3. {{c1::Submandibular}}
**SLO 22: Know the functions of saliva, composition of saliva, general structure of salivary glands, three primary salivary glands.
** SLO 23: Describe the regulation of saliva (ANS and main factors influencing the PNS)
• Both parasympathetic and sympathetic systems increase saliva secretion, however, parasympathetic influences are by far the most significant

Mucous cells: {{c1::secretes mucous (glycoproteins and bicarb protecting the stomach lining)}}
Chief cells: {{c1::secretes pepsinogen (low pH converts to pepsin, a protein-digesting enzyme)}}
Parietal cells: {{c1::secretes intrinsic factor (protein that binds vitamin B12 and is necessary for B12 absorption) and HCl (lowers pH which activates pepsin, protects against microorganisms, and helps digest)}}
 
Complex regulation system that has significant clinical implications
G cells are present in the stomach (not in the glands) and secrete gastrin
** SLO 25: Know the primary regulatory cells of the stomach, their roles, secretions/products, and impact of upregulation or downregulation
**SLO 30: Understand the protective and damaging factors to GI mucus layer and mucosa

Too much acid can cause: 
  • GERD (if gastric contents reflux) 
  • Peptic ulcers (if protective factors are compromised) 
  • Duodenal ulcers in small bowel (if protective factors are compromised)

Cephalic phase: Starts eating -> vagal center in medulla kickstarts {{c1::salivation and sends ACh signal to parietal cells and GRP to G cells}} -> parietal cells secrete {{c1::HCl}} -> G cells release {{c1::gastrin to help parietal cells::which hormone?}} -> gastrin recruits {{c1::ECL cells::What kind of cells?}} to {{c1::release histamine and help parietal cells more::Do what?}}
**SLO 28: Describe the cellular responses and interactions of the cephalic phase, gastric phase, and intestinal phase and how the gastric environment is returned to normal

Gastric phase: Stomach distension -> more vagus nerve signals to {{c1::increase HCl}} and the distension and food proteins directly activate {{c1::G cells::which cells?}} to release {{c1::more gastrin::which hormone?}} -> if drinking alcohol/caffeine, {{c1::G cells::which cells?}} are further stimulated -> {{c1::gastrin::which hormone?}} also recruits {{c1::Chief cells::which cells?}} to make {{c1::more pepsinogen::what enzyme?}} -> HCl converts {{c1::pepsinogen into pepsin::enzyme into what?}}.
** SLO 28: Describe the cellular responses and interactions of the cephalic phase, gastric phase, and intestinal phase and how the gastric environment is returned to normal

Intestinal phase: food bolus is converted to {{c1::chyme}} -> goes through {{c1::pylorus}} to the {{c1::duodenum}} -> high HCl levels signal {{c1::D cells::what kind of cells?}} to release {{c1::somatostatin::which hormone?}} -> {{c1::G cells and ECL cell::Which two types of cells?}} activity is slowed down -> stomach pH returns to normal -----> {{c1::GIP and Secretin}} are sent over by small bowel to further help D cells {{c1::inhibit acid secretion::do what?}}
**SLO 28:Describe the cellular responses and interactions of the cephalic phase, gastric phase, and intestinal phase and how the gastric environment is returned to normal

• Pancreatic juices (the “Exocrine Pancreas”)
    • HC03 to {{c1::neutralize incoming acidic chyme::do what?}}
    • Many digestive enzymes
  • Bile (from the liver/gallbladder)
    • Helps with {{c1::the digestion and absorption of lipids}}
    • Major components of bile are {{c1::bile salts and acids, phospholipids, and bilirubin (a heme breakdown product)}}
**SLO 29: Explain the basics of pancreatic juices and bile

• ETOH and Caffeine
    • Upregulate {{c1::G cell secretion of gastrin}}
    • Coffee is also acidic
**SLO 31: Explain the GI pathophysiology of ETOH, Caffeine, NSAIDs, Stress ulcers, smoking, H pylori

NSAIDS
  • Inhibit {{c1::prostaglandin synthesis (which inhibit parietal cells and ECL cells) }}
  • Direct topical irritant to {{c1::mucosa/epithelial cells  }}
    • Reason we have enteric coated aspirin (reduces irritation) 
    • We wouldn't want to give enteric coated aspirin for acute MI because {{c1::enteric-coated makes absorption slower; we want to take care of an acute MI quickly }}
**SLO 31: Explain the GI pathophysiology of ETOH, Caffeine, NSAIDs, Stress ulcers, smoking, H pylori

Stress ulcers  
  • Caused by {{c1::severe physiologic stress (sepsis, burns, mechanical ventilation in ICU), not anxiety }}
  • Decreased {{c1::HCO3 }}in mucous and decreased{{c1:: mucosal blood flow }}
**SLO 31: Explain the GI pathophysiology of ETOH, Caffeine, NSAIDs, Stress ulcers, smoking, H pylori

Smoking 
  • Inhibits {{c1::prostaglandins }}
  • Reduces {{c1::mucosal blood flow }}
  • Quitting smoking is associated with healing of {{c1::ulcers }}

H.pylori
  • Bacterial infection that hides in {{c1::protective mucus layer + causes damage/inflammation to mucosa of stomach and duodenum }}
    • Transmitted person-person, often groups of people and families will have infection. 
    • Chronic; can lead to gastritis, peptic ulcers, or even stomach cancer 
  • Produces {{c1::urease}} -> {{c1::breaks down urea into basic ammonia::what does this enzyme do?}} -> raises pH in local mucus to {{c1::protect bacteria from acid::do what? }}
  • Diagnosis: {{c1::urea breath test or stool antigen test }}
  • Treatment: {{c1::triple therapy - clarithromycin, amoxicillin/metronidazole, and proton pump inhibitor (could also add Bismuth) ::what abx are used?}}
SLO 31: Explain the GI pathophysiology of ETOH, Caffeine, NSAIDs, Stress ulcers, smoking, H pylori
Trace Object through GI tract: (mouth to anus)
*Know the anatomy discussed in this lecture and be able to trace the anatomical path of a substance from the mouth to the anus
*Know the anatomy discussed in this lecture and be able to trace the anatomical path of a substance from the mouth to the anus.

Characteristics: {{c1::Villi}} & {{c1::Crypts}}
Location: {{c1::small intestine}}
Function: Both increase {{c1::Surface Area}} and helps {{c1::with absorption}}
Disease involvement: {{c1::Celiac}} disease ({{c1::block folds}})
 
Characteristics: {{c1::Folds}} & {{c1::Rugae}}
Location: {{c1::stomach}}
Function: allow for {{c1::expansion}}

*Describe the villi and crypts and predict how changes in structure would impact function

From book:
-Structural features called villi and microvilli increase the surface area of the small intestine, maximizing the exposure of nutrients to digestive enzymes and creating a large absorptive surface.
-The epithelial cells lining the intestinal crypts secrete fluid and electrolytes (compared with the cells lining the villi, which absorb fluid and electrolytes)

• Pharmacodynamics:
Study of what {{c1::drugs}} do to the {{c1::body}} ({{c1::MOA}})

Ex: {{c1::Toxicity}} (side effect) and {{c1::Efficacy}}

  • Pharmacokinetics
 What the {{c1::body}} does to the {{c1::drugs}} ({{c1::ADME}}).
1. {{c1::Absorption}}
2. {{c1::Distribution}}
3. {{c1::Metabolism}}
4. {{c1::Elimination}}
*Define the terms: bioavailability, first-pass effect, pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics (ADME), and therapeutic window.

Therapeutic Window:

={{c1::Minimal effective dose(MEC desired)}} - {{c1::minimal toxic dose(MEC adverse)}}

Bioavailability (F)  =

{{c1::(AUC)o}}     
{{c1::(AUC)iv }} (100%)
 
Area {{c1::under the curve}} ({{c1::AUC}}) is measured
{{c1::Plasma levels}} are plotted against {{c1::time}}
*Define the terms: bioavailability, first-pass effect, pharmacodynamics, pharmacokinetics (ADME), and therapeutic window.

How does the drug get into blood stream?
{{c1::Permeation}} - drug has to pass through several {{c1::biological membranes}}
  • There are several mechanisms but the most important mechanism is {{c1::passive diffusion }} for most of drugs.
  • ONLY {{c1::lipid soluble}} or {{c1::unionized}} part of the drug can diffuse cross {{c1::plasma membrane}}
*Identify factors that affect drug absorption and predict resultant effects on the rate and extent of absorption.

Rules of AAA or BB for {{c1::absorption}}

AAA: {{c1::Acidic}} drugs are best {{c1::Absorbed}} from {{c1::Acidic}} environments
 
BB: {{c1::Basic}} drugs are {{c1::absorbed}} best in {{c1::Basic}} environments
 
pH
Gastric fluid

Small intestine
{{c1::5-8}}
Plasma

Mouth

*Recall the AAA/BB mnemonic for principles of absorption.

{{c1::UN-IONIZED}} is {{c1::lipid}} soluble, and absorbed
{{c1::Ionized (with + or -)}} is {{c1::water}} soluble, and excreted

*Recall the AAA/BB mnemonic for principles of absorption.
Extra Notes:
  • NH3: tertiary amine, unionized, lipid soluble
  • NH4+: quaternary amine, ionized, water soluble
  • Paired ions=Uncharged=Un-ionized=Lipid soluble
*Not an objective but in RED

{{c1::Drug}} = any agent used in the treatment or prevention of disease or the prevention of pregnancy
 
{{c1::Generic name}} – name of a drug that is the same between companies
   Eg. {{c1::Ibuprofen}}
*Not an objective but in RED

{{c1::Enteral}}: feed drugs by GI tract
Oral-
Disadvantages:
{{c1::First pass-}}-- metabolism of drug in GI and liver before the drug reaches blood circulation
 
{{c1::Bioavailability}} is the fraction of administered drug that gains access to the systemic circulation in an unchanged form
 
Oral Bioavailability is {{c1::less than 100%}} due to {{c1::first pass}}
 
Sublingual- lacks {{c1::First Pass }}
 
Rectal- bypass {{c1::liver}} (the veins below {{c1::pectinate line [dentate line]}} draining directly to the general circulation)
 
Disadvantage:
Drugs are put into rectum too deep passing {{c1::pectinate line}} then undergoes {{c1::first pass}}
*List common routes of drug administration and compare and contrast their relative advantages and disadvantages.

{{c1::Parenteral}}: feed drugs by non-GI route {{c1::(injection)}}
 
{{c1::Intravenous (IV)}}-
Advantage:
Bioavailability is {{c1::100}}%
 
{{c1::Intramuscular}} (IM)-
Advantages:
Fairly rapid absorption of {{c1::water}} soluble drugs
depot preparations ({{c1::slow releasing}})

{{c1::Subcutaneous (S.C)}}-
The drug injected then moves into {{c1::capillaries}} or reaches the bloodstream through the {{c1::lymphatic vessels }} {{c1::(insulin enter lymphatic vessel)}}
 
Eg. {{c1::protein}} drugs because such drugs would be digested in the digestive tract if they are taken orally
*List common routes of drug administration and compare and contrast their relative advantages and disadvantages.
*List common routes of drug administration and compare and contrast their relative advantages and disadvantages.

Space for correct procedure:
-Lumber puncture- {{c1::Intrathecal}} aka [{{c1::subarachnoid space}}]
-Epidural= {{c1::Epidural Space
*List common routes of drug administration and compare and contrast their relative advantages and disadvantages.
